Reproduced and distributed under the direction of the Clerk of the House. 
STATE OF MAINE 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
129TH LEGISLATURE 
FIRST REGULAR SESSION 
COlYfMITTEE AMENDMENT "B" to H.F. 743, L.D. 1001, Bill, "An Act Making 
Unified Appropriations and AlJocations for the Expenditures of State Government, 
General Fund and Other Funds, and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessary 
to the Proper Operations of State Govei:nrnent for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2019, 
June 30, 2020 and June 30, 2021" 
Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following: 
;Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do. not 
become effective until 90 days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and 
Whereas, the 90-day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 
fiscal year; and 
Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 
departments and institutions will become due and payable immediately; aod 
vVhereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 
the meaning of the Constitutio~ of Maine and require the following legislation as 
immediately necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety; n9w, 
therefore, · 
Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows: 
PART A 
Sec. A-1. Appropriations and allocations. The following appropriations and 
allocations are made. 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SERVICES, DEPARTIVIENT OF

Homestead Property Tax Exemption Reimbursement 0886  27 
Initiative: Provides funding to increase the homestead property tax exemption from 28 
$20,000 to $25,000 and to increase the reimb ursement to municipalities from 62.5% to 29 
70% for property tax years beginning April 1, 2020.  30

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 459 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Initiative: Establishes one Senior Laboratory Scientist position, one Office Specialist I 1 
position, one Computer Forensic Analyst position and one State Police Detective position 2 
and provides funding for All Other in order to restructur e the computer crimes unit to 3 
more effectively address the growing demand for digital forensic analysis and 4 
investigations of crimes involving advanced technological devices.  5

 9

Computer Crimes 0048  13 
Initiative: Transfers one Computer Forensic Analyst position from the State Police 14 
program, Federal Expenditures Fund to the Comput er Crimes program, General Fund and 15 
reallocates the funding in the State Police program, Federal Expenditures Fund to All 16 
Other. This transfer is part of the restructuring plan for this unit and recognizes that the 17 
current grant funding ends on September 3 0, 2019.  18

 23

Computer Crimes 0048  25 
Initiative: Transfers one Computer Forensic Analyst position from  the State Police 26 
program, Other Special Revenue Funds to the Computer Crimes program, General Fund 27 
and reallocates the funding in the State Police program, Other Special Revenue Funds to 28 
All Other.  This transfer is part of the restructuring plan for this  unit and recognizes the 29 
continuing decline in the revenue stream that supports this Other Special Revenue Funds 30 
account.  31

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT   
 1 
 
 
PART C  2 
Sec. C -1.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§7, ¶B, as amended by PL 2017, c. 284, Pt. 3 
C, §19, is further amended to read:  4 
B.  The annual targets for the state share percentage of the statewide adjust ed total 5 
cost of the components of essential programs and services are as follows.  6 
(1)  For fiscal year 2005 -06, the target is 52.6%.  7 
(2)  For fiscal year 2006 -07, the target is 53.86%.  8 
(3)  For fiscal year 2007 -08, the target is 53.51%.  9 
(4)  For fiscal ye ar 2008 -09, the target is 52.52%.  10 
(5) For fiscal year 2009 -10, the target is 48.93%.  11 
(6)  For fiscal year 2010 -11, the target is 45.84%.  12 
(7)  For fiscal year 2011 -12, the target is 46.02%.  13 
(8)  For fiscal year 2012 -13, the target is 45.87%.  14 
(9)  For fiscal  year 2013 -14, the target is 47.29%.  15 
(10)  For fiscal year 2014 -15, the target is 46.80%.  16 
(11)  For fiscal year 2015 -16, the target is 47.54%.  17 
(12)  For fiscal year 2016 -17, the target is 48.14%.  18

Sec. C -7.  Authorization of payments.  If the State's continued obligation for 21 
any individual component contained in those sections of this Part that set the total cost of 22 
funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and state 23 
contributions for that purpose  exceeds the level of funding provided for that component, 24 
any unexpended balances occurring in other programs may be applied to avoid proration 25 
of payments for any individual component. Any unexpended balances from this Part may 26 
not lapse but must be carr ied forward for the same purpose.  27 
Sec. C -8.  Limit of State's obligation.  Those sections of this Part that set the 28 
total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and 29 
state contributions for that purpose may not be const rued to require the State to provide 30 
payments that exceed the appropriation of funds for general purpose aid for local schools 31 
for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2019 and ending June 30, 2020.  32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3101.  Definitions  1 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 2 
have the following meanings.  3 
1.  Director.   "Director" means the Director of the Governor's Office of Policy 4 
Innovation  and Management  the Future  established by section 3102.  5 
2.  Office.   "Office" means the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and 6 
Management  the Future  established by section 3102.  7 
Sec. D -7.  5 MRSA §3 102, as amended by PL 2017, c. 284, Pt. GG, §4, is further 8 
amended to read:  9 
§3102.  Office established; purpose  10 
The Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the Future  is 11 
established in the Executive Department to facilitate achievement of lon g-term state goals 12 
and objectives and identification and implementation of opportunities to improve the 13 
efficiency and effectiveness of the performance of the functions of and delivery of 14 
services by State Government.  15 
Sec. D -8.  5 MRSA §3103, as enacted by  PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. DD, §5 and affected 16 
by §24, is amended to read:  17 
§3103.  Director  18 
The Director of the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the 19 
Future  is appointed by the Governor and serves at the pleasure of the Governor.  20 
Sec. D -9.  5 MRSA §13056, sub -§3, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. DD, §6 21 
and affected by §24, is further amended to read:  22 
3.  Conduct planning and research.   Conduct planning, research and analysis for 23 
department needs, but not macroeconomic forecasting, which is the responsibility of the 24 
Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the Future .  The department 25 
shall gather, maintain and have access to all economic and other information necessary to 26 
the performance of its duties;  27

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Promoting economic development and resource conservation; assistance to 1 
host communities.   To the extent practicable within existing resources, the Department 2 
of Economic and Community De velopment, the Governor's Energy Office and the 3 
Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the Future  shall provide, upon 4 
the request of a host community, assistance for the purpose of helping the host 5 
community maximize the economic development  and resource conservation benefits 6 
from tax payments and payments made pursuant to a community benefit agreement or a 7 
community benefits package in connection with expedited wind energy developments.  8 
As part of this assistance, the department and the Dep artment of Economic and 9 
Community Development shall support host communities in identifying additional 10 
funding and developing regional economic and natural resource conservation strategies.  11 
Sec. D -17.  38 MRSA §484, sub -§10, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. DD, 12 
§18 and affected by §24, is further amended to read:  13 
10.  Special provisions; wind energy development or offshore wind power 14 
project.  In the case of a grid -scale wind energy development, or an offshore wind power 15 
project with an aggregate generati ng capacity of 3 megawatts or more, the proposed 16 
generating facilities, as defined in Title 35 -A, section 3451, subsection 5:  17 
A.  Will be designed and sited to avoid unreasonable adverse shadow flicker effects;  18 
B.  Will be constructed with setbacks adequat e to protect public safety.  In making a 19 
finding pursuant to this paragraph, the department shall consider the recommendation 20 
of a professional, licensed civil engineer as well as any applicable setback 21 
recommended by a manufacturer of the generating facil ities; and  22 
C.  Will provide significant tangible benefits as determined pursuant to Title 35 -A, 23 
section 3454, if the development is an expedited wind energy development.  24 
The Department of Labor, the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  25 
the Future , the Governor's Energy Office and the Public Utilities Commission shall 26 
provide review comments if requested by the primary siting authority.  27 
For purposes of this subsection, "grid -scale wind energy development," "primary siting 28 
authority," "signi ficant tangible benefits" and "expedited wind energy development" have 29 
the same meanings as in Title 35 -A, section 3451.  30 
Sec. D -18.  Maine Revised Statutes amended; revision clause.    Wherever in 31 
the Maine Revised Statutes the words "Governor's Office of Policy and Management" 32 
appear or reference is made to that entity or those words, those words are amended to 33 
read or mean, as appropriate, "Governor's Office of Policy Innovation and the Future" 34 
and the Revisor of Statutes shall implement this revision whe n updating, publishing or 35 
republishing the statutes.  36 
Sec. D -19.  Rename Office of Policy and Management program.  37 
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Office of Policy and Management 38 
program within the Executive Department is renamed the Office of Policy Innovation and 39 
the Future program.  40

Sec. F -1.  5 MRSA §1710 -E, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. I, §6 and 19 
affected by §11, is further amended to read:  20 
§1710 -E.  Revenue Forecasting Committee; established; membership  21 
There is established the Revenue Forecasting Committee, referred to in this chapter 22 
as the "committee," for the purpose of providing the Governor,  the Legislature and the 23 
State Budget Officer with analyses, findings and recommendations relating to the 24 
projection of revenues for the General Fund and the Highway Fund based on economic 25 
assumptions recommended by the Consensus Economic Forecasting Commi ssion.  The 26 
committee includes the State Budget Officer, the Associate Commissioner for Tax Policy, 27 
the State Economist, an economist on the faculty of the University of Maine System 28 
selected by the chancellor, the Director of the Office of Fiscal and Prog ram Review and 29 
another member of the Legislature's nonpartisan staff familiar with revenue estimating 30 
issues appointed by the Legislative Council.   One of the 6 members must be selected by 31 
a majority vote of the committee members to serve as the chair of the committee.   32 
Beginning in calendar year 2019, the chair of the committee must be designated by a 33 
majority vote of the 6 members, from among the Associate Commissioner for Tax Policy, 34 
the Director of the Office of Fiscal and Program Review, the State Eco nomist, an 35 
economist on the faculty of the University of Maine System selected by the chancellor 36 
and another member of the Legislature's nonpartisan staff familiar with revenue 37 
estimating issues appointed by the Legislative Council.  The chair must be desi gnated on 38 
a rotating basis and serves a 2 -year term.  39

Sec. G -13.  36 MRSA §194 -D is enacted to read:  38 
§194 -D.  Background investigations  39 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 40 
following terms have the following meanings.  41 
A.  "Affected person" means a person w ho is:  42 
(1)  An applicant for employment with the bureau;  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 532 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (2)  A contractor for the bureau, including the contractor's employees, 1 
subcontractors and subcontractors' employees, who provides or is assigned to 2 
provide services to the bureau under an identified  contract. For the purposes of 3 
this subparagraph, "identified contract" means a contract that the assessor 4 
determines involves access or the substantial possibility of access to the bureau's 5 
information technology systems or to confidential tax information ; 6 
(3)  A current employee of the bureau; or  7 
(4)  An employee or contractor, including the contractor's respective employees, 8 
subcontractors and subcontractors' employees, of another state agency, if the 9 
assessor determines the employee's or contractor's du ties involve access or the 10 
substantial possibility of access to federal tax information obtained from the 11 
bureau.  12 
B.  "Confidential tax information" means any information the inspection or disclosure 13 
of which is limited or prohibited by section 191, includ ing federal tax information.  14 
C.  "Federal tax information" means a return and return information as defined in the 15 
Code, Section 6103(b) that is received directly from the United States Internal 16 
Revenue Service or obtained through a United States Internal Revenue Service - 17 
authorized secondary source and that is subject to the confidentiality protections and 18 
safeguarding requirements of the United States Internal Revenue Code and 19 
corresponding federal regulations and guidance. "Federal return information" doe s 20 
not include information in the possession of the State that is obtained from sources 21 
wholly independent from the United States Internal Revenue Service.  22 
2.  Background investigation requirements.  The assessor shall perform 23 
background investigations for affected persons in accordance with this subsection.  24 
A.  As part of the process of evaluating an affected person for employment with the 25 
bureau, a background investigation must be conducted before an offer of employment 26 
is extended.  27 
B.  A background invest igation for an affected person assigned to provide services to 28 
the bureau under an identified contract must be conducted before that affected person 29 
begins providing services to the bureau, and at least once every 10 years, as long as 30 
the affected person c ontinues providing services to the bureau.  31 
C.  As part of the process of evaluating an affected person for continued employment 32 
with the bureau, a background investigation must be conducted at least once every 10 33 
years.  If an affected person has not been subject to a background investigation within 34 
10 years prior to the effective date of this section, a background investigation must be 35 
conducted within one year of the effective date of this section.  36 
D.  A background investigation for an employee or contrac tor of another state agency 37 
must be conducted before that affected person is provided access, or the substantial 38 
possibility of access, to federal tax information obtained from the bureau, and at least 39 
once every 10 years, as long as the affected person co ntinues to have such access. 40 
However, if the assessor determines that the affected person has been subject to a 41 
background investigation that satisfies the background investigation standards 42 
established by the United States Internal Revenue Service regardi ng access to federal 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 533 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  tax information within the past 10 years, no further investigation is required under 1 
this subsection for the 10 -year period commencing at the time of the background 2 
investigation.  3 
The background investigation must include fingerprintin g and obtaining national criminal 4 
history record information from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and must satisfy the 5 
background investigation standards established by the United States Internal Revenue 6 
Service regarding access to federal tax informat ion. 7 
3.  Fingerprinting.  An affected person must consent to having fingerprints taken for 8 
use in background investigations in accordance with this section.  The State Police shall 9 
take or cause to be taken the affected person's fingerprints and shall forw ard the 10 
fingerprints to the Department of Public Safety, Bureau of State Police, State Bureau of 11 
Identification so that the State Bureau of Identification can conduct state and national 12 
criminal history record checks for the bureau.  The State Police may c harge the bureau for 13 
the expenses incurred in processing state and national criminal history record checks.  14 
The full fee charged under this subsection must be deposited in a dedicated revenue 15 
account for the State Bureau of Identification with the purpose  of paying costs associated 16 
with the maintenance and replacement of the criminal history record systems.  17 
4.  Confidentiality.  All information obtained by the assessor pursuant to this section 18 
is confidential and not a public record as defined in Title 1, section 402, subsection 3.  19 
The information must only be used for making decisions regarding the suitability of an 20 
affected person for new or continued employment with the bureau, to provide services to 21 
the bureau under an identified contract or to access federal tax information obtained from 22 
the bureau.  23 
5.  Affected person's access to criminal history record information.  The bureau 24 
shall provide an affected person with access to information obtained pursuant to this 25 
section, if requested, by providing a p aper copy of the criminal history record information 26 
directly to the affected person, but only after the bureau confirms that the affected person 27 
is the subject of the record.  In addition, the bureau shall publish guidance on requesting 28 
such information f rom the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  29 
6.  Disqualifying offenses; refusal to consent.  The assessor shall review the 30 
information obtained under this section and determine whether an affected person has a 31 
disqualifying offense that would prohibit authori zing that individual from accessing 32 
confidential tax information or federal tax information.  If an affected person refuses to 33 
consent to the background investigation requirements under this section, that affected 34 
person is considered to have a disqualifyi ng offense. If the affected person has a 35 
disqualifying offense:  36 
A.  The bureau may not employ or utilize that affected person in a position for which 37 
access to confidential tax information is required;  38 
B.  If the affected person is an employee of the burea u or is assigned to provide 39 
services to the bureau under an identified contract and the assessor has authorized the 40 
affected person to access confidential tax information, the bureau shall terminate that 41 
affected person's access and may remove that affecte d person from any position that 42 
involves access, or the substantial possibility of access, to confidential tax 43 
information.  If the affected person is an employee of the bureau, the bureau shall 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 534 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  make a reasonable effort to retain that person as an employee  in another position 1 
within the bureau that does not require access to confidential tax information; and  2 
C.  If the affected person is an employee or contractor of another state agency, the 3 
assessor shall notify the other agency and the agency shall termin ate the affected 4 
person's access, or substantial possibility of access, to federal tax information and 5 
may remove that affected person from any position that involves such access. If the 6 
affected person is an employee of the agency, the agency shall make a  reasonable 7 
effort to retain that person as an employee in another position that does not require 8 
access to federal tax information.  9

Sec. H -7.  Restriction on use of certain state -municipal revenue -sharing 14 
amounts in  fiscal year 2019 -20.  Notwithstanding any provision of law or municipal 15

woul d be based on the transfer to the Local Government Fund of a percentage of the 18

unde r this Part, the municipal officers for that municipality may use the difference 21 
between the amount of revenue sharing assumed in preparing the budget and the actual 22 
revenue sharing received pursuant to this Part without the requirement of approval by a 23 
town meeting or a municipal referendum if the funds are used for the repair or 24 
maintenance of roads or bridges within the municipality or the direct reduction of the 25 
property tax mill rate.  26

PART L  14 
Sec. L -1.  Voluntary employee incentive programs.   Notwithstanding the 15 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 903, subsections 1 and 2, the Commissioner of 16 
Administrative and Financial Services shall offer for use prior to July 1, 2021 special 17 
voluntary employee incentive programs for state employees, including a 50% workweek , 18 
flexible position staffing and time off without pay. Employee participation in a voluntary 19 
employee incentive program is subject to the approval of the employee's appointing 20 
authority.  21 
Sec. L -2.  Continuation of group health insurance.   Notwithstanding t he 22 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 285, subsection 7 and Title 5, section 903, the 23 
State shall continue to pay health and dental insurance benefits for a state employee who 24 
applies prior to July 1, 2021 and is approved to participate in a voluntar y employee 25 
incentive program under section 1 of this Part based upon the scheduled workweek in 26 
effect prior to the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  27 
Sec. L -3.  Continuation of group life insurance.   Notwithstanding the M aine 28 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 903 and 18056 and the rules of the Maine Public 29 
Employees Retirement System, the life, accidental death and dismemberment, 30 
supplemental and dependent insurance amounts for a state employee who applies prior to 31 
July 1, 2021 and is approved to participate in a voluntary employee incentive program 32 
under section 1 of this Part are based upon the scheduled hours of the employee prior to 33 
the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  34 
Sec. L -4.  G eneral Fund savings.   Notwithstanding the Maine Revised Statutes, 35 
Title 5, section 1585, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the General Fund savings 36 
resulting from the voluntary employee incentive programs under section 1 of this Part to 37 
the General F und Compensation and Benefit Plan account in the Department of 38 
Administrative and Financial Services. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the joint 39 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and 40

fiscal year 2019 -20 and no later than January 15, 2022 for fiscal year 2020 -21. 2

contrary, $350,000 in fiscal year 2 019-20 and $350,000 in fiscal year 2020 -21 of savings 4

PART M  7

Authority.   Notwithstanding any p rovision of law to the contrary, the State Controller 9 
shall carry any remaining balances in the Debt Service - Government Facilities Authority 10 
program in the Department of Administrative and Financial Services in each year of the 11 
2020 -2021 biennium into th e following fiscal year.  12 
PART N  13 
Sec. N -1.  Attrition savings.   Notwithstanding any provision of law to the 14 
contrary, the attrition rate for the 2020 -2021 biennium is 5% for judicial branch and 15 
executive branch departments and agencies only. The attrition r ate for subsequent biennia 16 
is 1.6%.  17 
Sec. N -2.  Calculation and transfer; attrition savings.   The State Budget 18 
Officer shall calculate the amount of the savings in section 3 of this Part that applies 19 
against each General Fund account for all executive bran ch departments and agencies 20 
statewide and shall transfer the amounts by financial order upon the approval of the 21 
Governor. These transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal years 22 
2019 -20 and 2020 -21. The State Budget Officer shall subm it to the Joint Standing 23 
Committee on Appropriations and Financial Affairs a report of the transferred amounts 24 
no later than September 1, 2020.  25 
Sec. N -3.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 26 
allocations are made.  27

Sec. T -2.  7 MRSA §3906 -B, sub -§16, as amended by PL 2009, c. 548, §1, is 22 
further amended to read:  23 
16.  Animal welfare auxiliary fund.   The commissioner may accept gifts, donations, 24 
bequests, en dowments, grants and matching funds from any private or public source for 25 
the purposes of ensuring the humane and proper treatment of animals and enhancing the 26 
administration and enforcement of this Part and Title 17, chapter 42.  The commissioner 27

auxiliary fund.  All gifts, donations, bequests, endowments, grants, proceeds and 30

endowment, grant or matching funds accepted with a stipulated purpose may be used only 33 
for that pur pose.  34

laws pertain to equines and for costs associated with department laboratory services 38

Sec. Y -2.  12 MRSA §1825, as amended by PL 2009, c. 27, §1; PL  2011, c. 657, 32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 543 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1825.  Administer certain funds  1 
The bureau shall administer funds relating to state parks and historic sites, municipal 2 
recreation and recreation management on lands cl assified as state parks or historic sites 3 
pursuant to this chapter. These funds include but are not limited to the following:  4 
1.  Maine State Parks and Recreational Facilities Development Fund.   The Maine 5 
State Parks and Recreational Facilities Development  Fund is established within the 6 
bureau for the purpose of developing, maintaining and managing state parks and other 7 
recreational facilities on lands owned or leased by the bureau.  8 
Income from legislative appropriation, gifts, grants, bequests and other so urces approved 9 
by the Legislature may be deposited into this fund.  Any interest earned on money in the 10 
fund must also be credited to the fund.  The Maine State Parks and Recreational Facilities 11 
Development Fund is nonlapsing and all funds are subject to a llocation by the 12 
Legislature.  13 
1-A.  Parks General Operations Fund . The Parks General Operations Fund is 14 
established within the bureau for the purpose of developing, maintaining and managing 15 
state parks and other recreational facilities on lands owned or le ased by the bureau.  16 
Income from legislative appropriation, gifts, grants, bequests, the Maine Environmental 17 
Trust Fund in accordance with section 10255, subsection 3 and any other sources 18 
approved by the Legislature may be deposited in this fund.  Any inte rest earned on money 19 
in the fund must be credited to the fund. The Parks General Operations Fund is 20 
nonlapsing and all funds are subject to allocation by the Legislature.  21 
2.  Maine State Parks Fund.   The Maine State Parks Fund is established within the 22 
bureau.  The fund receives money from the Maine Environmental Trust Fund in 23 
accordance with section 10255, subsection 3.  The bureau shall use money in the fund for 24 
major and minor capital improvements, maintenance, repairs and operations at state parks 25 
and h istoric sites.  26 
The Maine State Parks Fund is nonlapsing and all funds are subject to allocation by the 27 
Legislature.  28 
3.  Municipal Recreation Fund.   The bureau shall administer a state grant -in-aid 29 
fund known as the Municipal Recreation Fund.  The bureau is  responsible for 30 
administering all money made available to the fund. Grants -in-aid may be made by the 31 
bureau out of the fund as follows.  32 
A.  The bureau may make grants to assist municipalities and other political 33 
subdivisions in the capital improvement of public park and recreation facilities for 34 
projects the total cost of each one of which does not exceed $5,000.  Such a grant 35 
may not exceed 75% of the approved project cost.  A municipality may not receive 36 
more than one grant under this paragraph in any fi scal year.  37 
B.  For those projects that are approved to receive federal financial assistance under 38 
the Federal  federal  Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965,  (P.L.  Public 39 
Law 88-578) , as amended, the bureau may make a supplemental grant not to exce ed 40 
40% of the approved project cost.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 544 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  The bureau may make grants to assist municipalities and other political 1 
subdivisions in the development and implementation of recreation programs. Eligible 2 
costs for the program grants include, but are not limited t o, employment of personnel, 3 
transportation and noncapital equipment or supplies. Any grant made under this 4 
paragraph in any single fiscal year may not exceed $1,000 or 50% of the project cost, 5 
whichever is less.  6 
Funds credited to the Municipal Recreation F und are nonlapsing.  7 
4.  Forest Recreation Resource Fund.   The bureau may construct and maintain 8 
public campsites to prevent forest fires by providing fire -safe sites and preventing a 9 
proliferation of private fires and to provide recreation opportunities on  lands within its 10 
jurisdiction and elsewhere in the State's forests where there is inadequate provision of 11 
private, primitive campsites.  12 
For the purpose of carrying out these activities, the bureau may accept voluntary services 13 
and other contributions purs uant to this chapter; enter into leases and other agreements; 14 
and, pursuant to Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter II 2-A, establish rules and a schedule of 15 
fees for the use of these campsites.  All such fees and other revenues derived from grants, 16 
contributi ons, contracts and transfers to carry out the purposes of this subsection must be 17 
deposited in a nonlapsing account, to be called the Forest Recreation Resource Fund, 18 
which is a separate unit within the Parks General Operations Fund  to be used for the 19 
purposes of this subsection.  All funds in this account are subject to allocation by the 20 
Legislature.  21 
5.  State Parks Improvement Fund established; sale of merchandise. The State 22 
Parks Improvement Fund, referred to in this section as "the fund," is established  within 23 
the bureau.  The fund is nonlapsing and is a separate unit within the Parks General 24 
Operations program .  The bureau may sell within parks or historic sites general 25 
merchandise that is distinctive to the parks or historic sites or useful to the enjo yment of 26 
the parks or historic sites.  Items that may be sold include, but are not limited to, hats, 27 
coffee mugs, bumper stickers, t -shirts, tote bags and firewood.  Merchandise sold by the 28 
bureau must be of good quality, appropriate for sale by the bureau  and sold for a 29 
reasonable fee. The bureau also may rent items to be used for the enjoyment of the park 30 
or historic site, including, but not limited to, rowboats, canoes, kayaks and bicycles.  To 31 
the extent the bureau needs to contract with vendors to obta in goods or services in order 32 
to develop, create or manufacture merchandise for sale or lease, the commissioner shall, 33 
to the maximum extent practicable, contract with vendors located in this State.  Goods 34 
and services purchased by the bureau for sale or l ease under this section must be procured 35 
in accordance with Title 5, chapter 155.  All proceeds from the sale or lease of 36 
merchandise pursuant to this subsection must be deposited in the fund and used for the 37 
operation and maintenance of parks.  38

PART NN  9 
Sec. NN -1.  Transfers and adjustments to position count.   The Commissioner 10 
of Corrections shall review the current organizational structure of the Department of 11 
Corrections to improve organizational efficiency and cost -effectiveness and shal l 12 
recommend transfers of positions and available balances.  Notwithstanding any provision 13 
of law to the contrary, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the position counts and 14 
available balances by financial order, in order to achieve the purposes of thi s section, 15 
from July 1st to December 1st of each fiscal year of the 2020 -2021 biennium.  Position 16 
adjustments made after December 1st and before July 1st of each fiscal year may not be 17 
considered an adjustment to position count or appropriations.  The tran sfer and 18 
adjustment authorized by this section must comply with the requirements of the Maine 19 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1585.  Any transfer or adjustment pursuant to this 20 
section that would result in a program or mission change or facility closure  must be 21 
reported by the Bureau of the Budget to the joint standing committee of the Legislature 22 
having jurisdiction over criminal justice and public safety matters for review before the 23 
associated financial order is submitted to the Governor for approval;  these transfers are 24 
considered adjustments to authorized position count, appropriations and allocations.  25

Sec. UU -3.  20-A MRSA §15689, sub -§7-A is enacted to read:  12 
7-A.  Adjustment for minimum teacher salary.   Beginning in fiscal year 2020 -21, 13 
the commissioner shall, in accordance with this subsection, increase the state share of the 14 
total allocation to a qualifying school administrative unit by an amount necessary to 15 
achieve the minimum salary for certified teachers established in section 13407.  16 
A.  As used in this subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, "qualifying 17 
school administrative unit" means a school administrative unit that t he commissioner 18 
determines to have a locally established salary schedule with a minimum teacher 19 
salary of less than $40,000 in school year 2019 -2020. As used in this subsection, 20 
unless the context otherwise indicates, "incremental salary increases" means t he 21 
incremental increases in the salaries of teachers employed by a qualifying school 22 
administrative unit in school year 2019 -2020 necessary to meet the minimum salary 23 
requirements of section 13407 from fiscal year 2020 -21 to fiscal year 2023 -24. 24 
B.  The co mmissioner shall allocate the funds appropriated by the Legislature in 25 
accordance with the following.  26 
(1)  The amount of increased funds provided to qualifying school administrative 27 
units under this subsection must be the amount necessary to fund the incre mental 28 
salary increases specified in this subsection.  29 
(2) The number of teachers eligible for incremental salary increases in a 30 
qualifying school administrative unit for a fiscal year must be based on the 31 
information supplied to the department pursuant to section 13407 in that fiscal 32 
year.  33 
(3) The increased funds provided under this subsection must be issued to 34 
qualifying school administrative units as an adjustment to the state school 35 
subsidy for distribution to the teachers. Qualifying school administrati ve units 36 
shall use the payments provided under this subsection to provide salary 37 
adjustments to those teachers eligible for incremental salary increases. The 38 
department shall collect the necessary data to allow the funds to be included in a 39 
qualifying scho ol administrative unit's monthly subsidy payments beginning no 40 
later than February 1st of each fiscal year.  41

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART VV  1 
Sec. VV -1.  Lease -purchase authorization; Department of Education's 2 
learning technology program.   Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Ti tle 5, 3 
section 1587, the Department of Education may enter into financing arrangements in 4 
fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21 for the acquisition of portable learning devices and 5 
support systems for students and educators to support the operations of the depa rtment's 6 
learning technology program. The financing agreements may not exceed 4 years in 7 
duration and $50,000,000 in principal costs for the department's learning technology 8 
program. The interest rate may not exceed 8%, and the total interest costs may not  exceed 9 
$4,000,000. The annual principal and interest costs must be paid from the appropriate line 10 
category allocations in the Department of Education. The State is authorized to extend the 11 
provisions of the lease -purchase agreement on behalf of school adm inistrative units as 12 
long as all costs of the extension are borne by the school administrative units.  13

§2892.  Tax imposed  19 
For the state fiscal year beginning on July 1, 2003, a tax is imposed against each 20 
hospital in the State.  The tax is equal to .74% of net operating revenue for the tax year as 21 
identified on the hospital's most recent audited annual fin ancial statement for that tax 22 
year.  Delinquent tax payments are subject to Title 22, section 3175 -C. 23 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2004, a tax is imposed annually 24 
against each hospital in the State.  The tax is equal to 2.23% of the  hospital's net 25 
operating revenue as identified in the hospital's audited financial statement for the 26 
hospital's taxable year.  For the state fiscal year beginning July 1, 2004, the hospital's 27 
taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during ca lendar year 2002.  For the 28 
state fiscal year beginning July 1, 2005, the hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal 29 
year that ended during calendar year 2003.  For state fiscal years beginning on or after 30 
July 1, 2006 but before July 1, 2008, the hos pital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year 31 
that ended during calendar year 2004.  32 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2008 but before July 1, 2010 , the 33 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar  year 2006.  34 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2010 but before July 1, 2013 , the 35 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2008.  36 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2013 but bef ore July 1, 2017 , the 37 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2012.  38 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2017 but before July 1, 2019 , the 39 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year t hat ended during calendar year 2014.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 560 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2019 but before July 1, 2021, the 1 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2016.  2

PART JJJ  16 
Sec. JJJ -1.  Emergency rule -making authority; health and human 17 
services matters.   The Department of Health and Human Services is authorized to 18 
adopt emergency rules under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 8054 and 8073 19 
as necessary to implement those provisions of this Act over which the department has 20 
subject matter jurisdiction for which specific authority has not been provided i n any other 21 
Part of this Act without the necessity of demonstrating that immediate adoption is 22 
necessary to avoid a threat to public health, safety or general welfare.  23 
PART KKK  24 
Sec. KKK -1.  Study of the new Medicaid expansion population.   The 25 
Department of  Health and Human Services shall conduct a study of the population 26 
covered under the expansion of Medicaid.  The department, as part of the study, shall 27 
examine the per capita cost of enrollees; changes in uncompensated care; reimbursement 28 
rates and revenu e from Medicaid compared to other payers; value -based purchasing 29 
options; previous insurance status of new members; the impact of the expansion on 30 
private insurers and the economy; and any other element necessary to inform future 31 
policy decisions by the de partment.  The department shall fund this study within existing 32 
resources.  33

PART QQQ  25 
Sec. QQQ -1.  5 MRSA §7054 -C, as enacted by PL 2017, c. 261, §1, is amended 26 
to read:  27 
§7054 -C.  Person with disability preference  28 
1.  Definiti ons.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 29 
following terms have the following meanings.  30 
A.  "Person with a disability" means a person who has been determined by a qualified 31 
professional to have a physical or mental impairmen t that constitutes a substantial 32 
barrier to employment but who can benefit in terms of an employment outcome from 33 
the provision of vocational rehabilitation services  a physical or mental impairment 34 
that substantially limits one or more of the person's majo r life activities . 35 
B.  "Qualified professional" means a vocational rehabilitation counselor or other 36 
professional with advanced disability training and certification.  37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 564 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  "Special appointment program" means the program established by rule by the 1 
Department  of Administrative and Financial Services, Bureau of Human Resources to 2 
provide persons with disabilities increased access to positions in the classified 3 
service.  4 
D.  "Ticket to Work program" means the Ticket to Work and Self -Sufficiency 5 
Program under Sect ion 1148 of the federal Social Security Act.  6 
2.  Interview.  In filling a position in the classified service, the employing agency 7 
shall offer an interview to a person with a disability who is eligible for the Ticket to Work 8 
program and  who meets the minim um qualifications established for the position and to a 9 
person who has been determined by a qualified professional to have a disability and who 10 
meets the minimum qualifications established for the position . 11 
3.  Guidance and referral if not hired.  If a per son with a disability applies for a 12 
position described in subsection 2 but is not selected, the Department of Administrative 13 
and Financial Services, Bureau of Human Resources shall provide guidance to the person 14 
regarding other available state positions , including opportunities in the special 15 
appointment program,  for which the person might qualify.  The Bureau of Human 16 
Resources may also refer the person to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Rehabilitation 17 
Services for potential vocational rehabilitation se rvices if the person has not been referred 18 
by a qualified professional , including opportunities in the special appointment program . 19 
4.  Retention preference.  In any reduction in personnel in the state service, 20 
employees who are eligible for the Ticket to Work program or who are  persons with 21 
disabilities must be retained in preference to all other competing employees in the same 22 
classification with equal seniority, status and performance reviews.  23 
5.  Right to nondisclosure.  A person with a disability or wh o is eligible for the 24 
Ticket to Work program  has the right to not disclose that person's disability at the time of 25 
hire but may not assert a right to a retention preference pursuant to subsection 4 at a later 26 
date.  27

unemployment benefit program of the Federal Government.  Any overpayments subject 34 
to this subsection may be deducted from any future benefits payable to the individual 35 
under the laws of this State or of another state or under an unemployme nt program of the 36 
Federal Government.  37 
In any case in which under this subsection a claimant is liable to repay any amount to the 38 
agency of another state, such amounts may be collected without interest by civil action in 39 
the name of the commissioner acting as agent for such agency.  40

account  may not be  used for any other purpose.  11

A business may apply to the commissioner for certification as a qualified Pine Tree 10 
Development Zone business.  Upon review and determination by the commissioner that a 11 
business is a qualified Pine Tree Development Zone business, t he commissioner shall 12 
issue a letter of certification to the business that includes a description of the qualified 13 
business activity for which the letter is being issued.  Prior to issuing a letter of 14 
certification, the commissioner must find that the busi ness activity will not result in a 15 
substantial detriment to existing businesses in the State.  In order to make this 16 
determination, the commissioner shall consider those factors the commissioner 17 
determines necessary to measure and evaluate the effect of th e proposed business activity 18 
on existing businesses, including whether any adverse economic effect of the proposed 19 
business activity on existing businesses is outweighed by the contribution to the 20 
economic well -being of the State.  The State Economist must  review applications under 21 
this section and provide an advisory opinion to assist the commissioner in making 22 
findings under this section.   The commissioner shall provide a copy of the letter of 23 
certification to the State Tax Assessor.  24

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  10.  Special provisions; wind energy development or offshore wind power 1 
proje ct.  In the case of a grid -scale wind energy development, or an offshore wind power 2 
project with an aggregate generating capacity of 3 megawatts or more, the proposed 3 
generating facilities, as defined in Title 35 -A, section 3451, subsection 5:  4 
A.  Will be designed and sited to avoid unreasonable adverse shadow flicker effects;  5 
B.  Will be constructed with setbacks adequate to protect public safety.  In making a 6 
finding pursuant to this paragraph, the department shall consider the recommendation 7 
of a profess ional, licensed civil engineer as well as any applicable setback 8 
recommended by a manufacturer of the generating facilities; and  9 
C.  Will provide significant tangible benefits as determined pursuant to Title 35 -A, 10 
section 3454, if the development is an exp edited wind energy development.  11 
The Department of Labor, the Governor's Office of Policy and Management,  the 12 
Governor's Energy Office and the Public Utilities Commission shall provide review 13 
comments if requested by the primary siting authority.  14 
For purpo ses of this subsection, "grid -scale wind energy development," "primary siting 15 
authority," "significant tangible benefits" and "expedited wind energy development" have 16 
the same meanings as in Title 35 -A, section 3451.  17

PART RRRR  23 
Sec. RRRR -1.  Strategic econ omic plan.  The Department of Economic and 24 
Community Development, in collaboration with public and private constituents, shall 25 
facilitate the creation of a 10 -year strategic economic plan, referred to in this section as 26 
"the strategic plan," that recommend s breakthrough strategies for increased economic 27 
prosperity for all citizens of the State in all regions, ultimately measured by increased 28 
household income, a growing workforce and sustainable business development.  29 
The strategic plan must extend broadly fr om the Maine Innovation Economy 30 
Advisory Board's 2017 innovation economy action plan created pursuant to the Maine 31 
Revised Statutes, Title 10, section 949 and seek to leverage private and federal 32 
investment, particularly in areas of scientific research and  commercialization.  The 33 
strategic plan's strategic goals must include the following:  34 
1.  To drive the value -added contribution per job from $87,160 to a goal identified by 35 
the Department of Economic and Community Development;  36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 580 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  To equitably grow the ann ual median wage per job from $31,550 to a goal 1 
identified by the Department of Economic and Community Development; and  2 
3.  To grow the workforce from 700,000 workers to a goal identified by the 3 
Department of Economic and Community Development.  4 
The strategi c plan must include sufficient assignments of accountability to ensure 5 
execution of the plan with sufficient metrics for effective management.  6 
The strategic plan must include an analysis of gaps in funding and policy and 7 
recommendations that ensure dependa ble continuity of access to capital across business 8 
start-up stages from equity investments, seed capital tax credits, start -up grants and direct, 9 
revolving and commercial loans with clear benchmarks, rigorous accountability, public 10 
transparency and risk m itigation that protect public benefits.  11 
Following a comprehensive assessment and trend analysis of research and 12 
development and business and commercial assets in the State, the Department of 13 
Economic and Community Development shall ensure that the strategi c plan includes 14 
consideration of but is not limited to directing policy supports that suit economic 15 
development in the emerging sectors of: life sciences and biomedical technology, 16 
environmental and renewable energy technology, information technology, adva nced 17 
technologies for forestry and agriculture, aquaculture and marine technology, composites 18 
and advanced materials and precision manufacturing.  19 
The strategic plan must complement and support other concurrent and parallel state 20 
planning initiatives on ene rgy and broadband connectivity such as the comprehensive 21 
state energy plan pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 2, section 9, subsection 3, 22 
paragraph C, the Statewide Broadband Action Plan of the Department of Economic and 23 
Community Development da ted March 2018 and the Detailed 2019 -2021 Strategic Plan 24 
for Broadband Service in Maine created by the ConnectME Authority in February 2019.  25 
The Department of Economic and Community Development shall establish a steering 26 
committee composed of representativ es from the Department of Economic and 27 
Community Development, the Finance Authority of Maine and the Department of Labor 28 
and the State Economist; the steering committee shall guide the development of the 29 
strategic plan.  30 
The Department of Economic and Commu nity Development shall establish a work 31 
team, and the work team shall develop the content of the strategic plan.  The work team 32 
must include, but is not limited to, the members of the steering committee and 33 
representatives from a state business organizatio n, the Maine Technology Institute, the 34 
Maine Development Foundation, a venture capital fund operating in the State, the office 35 
of the President of the University of Maine and a state building and trades organization.  36 
The content of the strategic plan must be informed by the work team and developed 37

the United States Department of Health and Human Services, the National Institutes of 44

Sec. UUUU -2.  Development of recommendations; report.   In order to meet 4

Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, section 4501, the Department of Education shall 7

PART VVVV  23 
Sec. VVVV -1.  Legislature to contract for independent review of the 24 
State's  early childhood special education services.   The Legislature, through the 25 
Joint Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs, referred to in this Part as 26 
"the joint standing committee," may contract with a qualified research and technical 27 
assistan ce entity to conduct pursuant to sections 5 and 6 an independent review of the 28 
State's early childhood special education services and develop recommendations and an 29 
implementation plan.  30 
Sec. VVVV -2.  Assistance; request for proposals process.   At the direc tion of 31 
the joint standing committee, the Office of the Executive Director of the Legislative 32 
Council, referred to in this Part as "the office," shall develop and administer a request for 33 
proposals process to permit the Legislature, through the joint stand ing committee, to 34 
award a contract pursuant to section 1.  The office, with the advice and assistance of the 35 
Independent Review Advisory Committee, established under section 4 and referred to in 36 
this Part as "the advisory committee," and in consultation wi th and with the approval of 37 
the joint standing committee, shall:  38 
1. Develop and administer a request for proposals process in accordance with section 39 
3; 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 584 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2. Administer the contract entered into pursuant to section 1, including monitoring 1 
the research and te chnical assistance entity's performance in meeting deadlines, providing 2 
deliverables pursuant to sections 5 and 6 and complying with other terms of the contract; 3 
and 4 
3. Within available resources, provide other assistance to the joint standing 5 
committee re lating to the contract and the purposes of this Part.  6 
Sec. VVVV -3.  Request for proposals; standards and selection process.   7 
The office, with the advice and assistance of the advisory committee, and in consultation 8 
with and with the approval of the joint s tanding committee, shall administer a request for 9 
proposals process in accordance with this section.  10 
1.  The qualifications of a research and technical assistance entity submitting a 11 
proposal must include, but are not limited to, the financial, technical a nd operational 12 
capacity of the entity to conduct state -level education policy research and fiscal analysis, 13 
as demonstrated by the entity's professional experience and expertise.  14 
2.  With the approval of the joint standing committee, the office shall issue  a request 15 
for proposals and publish notice of the request on the Legislature's publicly accessible 16 
website and through advertisements in 2 or more public newspapers circulated wholly or 17 
in part in the State and may provide any further notice of the reques t to any other media 18 
or entities, as approved by the joint standing committee. The notice must provide that the 19 
office will accept, for 30 days after the first date of publication, proposals from qualified 20 
research and technical assistance entities that me et the standards approved by the joint 21 
standing committee.  22 
3. After proposals have been received and the period for accepting proposals has 23 
expired, the office, with the advice and counsel of the advisory committee, shall evaluate 24 
the proposals and present  a ranking of or recommendations regarding the proposals to the 25 
joint standing committee. The joint standing committee shall review the 26 
recommendations and choose the proposal it wishes to accept. The joint standing 27 
committee shall notify the Executive Dir ector of the Legislative Council of its selection 28 
of a proposal. The executive director shall execute a contract with the selected research 29 
and technical assistance entity on behalf of the Legislature.  30 
4. Notwithstanding the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 1 , section 402, except for the 31 
name and mailing address of a research and technical assistance entity that submits a 32 
proposal, the proposal and all other materials prepared, used or submitted in connection 33 
with the proposal are confidential and are not subj ect to public review until the period for 34 
accepting proposals has expired.  35 
Sec. VVVV -4.  Independent Review Advisory Committee.   The Independent 36 
Review Advisory Committee is established to advise the office and joint standing 37 
committee on matters related t o developing a request for proposals and administering the 38 
contract entered into pursuant to this Part. The advisory committee consists of the 39 
following members:  40 
1. The Commissioner of Education or the commissioner's designee;  41 
2.  The Commissioner of Healt h and Human Services or the commissioner's designee;  42

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. VVVV -5.  Scope of the r eview.   The contract entered into pursuant to 1 
section 1 must require an objective evaluation of the State's early childhood special 2 
education services from birth to 5 years of age.  The evaluation must include, but is not 3 
limited to, comparisons between th is State and other comparable states and an 4 
implementation plan for the transition of services from the Child Development Services 5 
System under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, section 7209 to local school 6 
administrative units and must address the f ollowing:  7 
1. National trends and relevant models of governing and delivering early childhood 8 
special education systems in other states and jurisdictions that hold the potential for 9 
enhancing the effectiveness, efficiency or accountability of the early chil dhood special 10 
education system in the State;  11 
2. The short -term and long -term costs and benefits of the proposed plan to restructure 12 
the Child Development Services System as presented to the Legislature in An Act To 13 
Reorganize the Provision of Services for Children with Disabilities from Birth to 5 Years 14 
of Age, L.D. 1715 from the First Regular Session of the 129th Legislature;  15 
3. The impact that the proposed plan will have on the following:  16 
A. Current Child Development Services System staff, including but n ot limited to the 17 
potential impact on staff retirement and how any negative impact on staff retirement 18 
can be reduced or eliminated and whether Child Development Services System 19 
employees would become employees of the local school administrative unit or th e 20 
State;  21 
B. Current school administrative unit staff;  22 
C. The provision of services for children birth to 3 years of age; and  23 
D. Due process complaints;  24 
4. The development of recommendations for an early childhood special education 25 
services program plan for  the State, which must include, but is not limited to:  26 
A. Models of best practices;  27 
B. Fiscally sound budget forecasting, including all possible revenue streams and 28 
updated costs;  29 
C. Transportation services;  30 
D. Data systems, including a billing system, a s ystem that allows coordination with 31 
the MaineCare program and a case management documentation system;  32 
E. A timeline for the implementation of the plan under this section;  33 
F. A procedure for data collection and analysis conducted by the Maine Education 34 
Policy Research Institute;  35 
G. A method for assessing a school administrative unit's capacity for implementing 36 
early childhood special education programs;  37 
H. Training requirements for service providers and leaders;  38 
I. A public information communication strategy  for implementation of the plan;  39

Veterans' Homes nursing facility.  Rules adopted pursuant to this section are routine 26 
technical rules as defined in the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 27 
2-A. 28

A.  To make loans to school administrative units for school repair and renovation.  10 
(1)  The following repair and renovation needs receive Priority 1 status:  11

(b)  Bringing a school building into compliance with the federal Americans 13 
with Disabilities Act, 42 United States Code, Section 12101 et seq.;  14

but not limited to, wa ter lead abatement or mitigation pursuant to Title 22, 17 
section 2604 -B; and  18

installations or improvements necessary to increase school facility security.  20

and doors and water or septic systems, other than water lead abatement or 22 
mitigation pursuant to Title 22, section 2604 -B, receive Priority 2 status.  23 
(3)  Repairs and improvements related to energy and water c onservation receive 24 
Priority 3 status.  25

retrofit learning spaces to accommodate the provision of services for children 27 
with disabilities who are 3 to 5 years of age,  receive Prio rity 4 status.  28

PART AAAAA  6 
Sec. AAAAA -1.  20-A MRSA §15688 -A, sub -§1, as repealed and replaced by 7 
PL 2017, c. 420, §8, is amended to read:  8 
1.  Career and technical education program components.  Beginning in fiscal year 9 
2018 -19, the allocation for career and technical education centers and career and 10 
technical education regions is based upon a model that recognizes program components 11 
that have been approved by the department pursuant to chapter 313 for:  12 
A.  Direct instruction.  The direct instruction component includes personnel costs for 13 
teachers, education technicians for programs and clinical supervisors for health care 14 
programs.  The allocat ion for direct instruction is the sum of the costs as determined 15 
based on the following components, which the commissioner shall determine 16 
annually:  17 
(1)  A teacher salary matrix.  In determining the teacher salary matrix for each 18 
program, the commissioner shall give consideration to the most recent available 19 
data regarding years of education experience and years of professional work 20 
experience relevant to instructional assignment;  21 
(2)  Student -to-teacher ratios for each program;  22 
(3)  The number of education  technicians required for purposes of instructional 23 
support, based on student enrollment and program requirements.  The 24 
commissioner shall calculate the education technician allocation by multiplying 25 
the number of education technicians required by the stat ewide average salary for 26 
full-time education technicians, based on the most recent available salary data, 27 
but shall ensure that each career and technical education center or career and 28 
technical education region is allocated at least one full -time educatio n technician; 29 
and 30 
(4)  The clinical supervision staffing level necessary for each program requiring 31 
such staffing, based on student enrollment as determined pursuant to paragraph 32 
G; 33 
B.  Central administration.  The central administration component includes  personnel 34 
costs for directors, assistant directors and clerical staff working in career and 35 
technical education centers and career and technical education regions, as well as 36 
business managers working in career and technical education regions.  The centra l 37 
administration allocation is the sum of:  38 
(1)  Costs for personnel for each career and technical education center and career 39 
and technical education region, as follows:  40

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (a)  A director, the allocation for which must be for one full -time equivalent;  1 
(b)  A n assistant director, the allocation for which must be based on student 2 
enrollment as determined pursuant to paragraph G but may not exceed one 3 
full-time equivalent;  4 
(c)  Clerical staff, the allocation for which must be for at least one full -time 5

expenditures for nonpersonnel costs to personnel costs;  14

footage of the career and technical education center or career and technical ed ucation 31 
region building by an amount per square foot, as determined by the commissioner;  32

coordination, career preparation, instructional technology, professional development, 34 
student assessment and program safety.  The other student and staff support 35 
allocation is the sum of the costs for:  36

collaborate with sending school guidance counselors in ord er to maximize 38 
student participation at the middle school and high school grade levels;  39

region student services coordinators, the allocation for which must be based on 2 
student enr ollment, as determined pursuant to paragraph G, but no less than one 3 
full-time equivalent;  4

section 15678, subsection 5, paragraph B; and  6

Sec. AAAAA -2.  20-A MRSA §15688 -A, sub -§1-A is enacted to read:  15 
1-A.  Transition period for career and technical education program components.   16 
In fiscal year 2020 -21, fiscal year 2021 -22 and fiscal year 2022 -23, referred to in this 17 
subsection as "the transition period," the total allocation for career and technical 18 
education centers and career and technical educatio n regions is subject to a transition 19 
period adjustment to align the total allocation for career and technical education centers 20 
and career and technical education regions with the career and technical education 21 
program components in subsection 1.  22 
A.  In ea ch fiscal year of the transition period, the commissioner shall identify each 23 
career and technical education center and career and technical education region for 24 
which the sum of the components in subsection 1, paragraphs A to E is less than the 25 
most recen t expenditure data, as adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the 26 
allocation year, or more than the most recent expenditure data, as adjusted for 27 
inflation to the year prior to the allocation year.  28 
B.  In each fiscal year of the transition period, the  commissioner shall calculate an 29 
adjustment to the total allocation for each career and technical education center and 30 
career and technical education region identified pursuant to paragraph A.  The 31 
calculation must be based on the amounts necessary to tran sition the career and 32 
technical education center or career and technical education region to a total 33 
allocation that is equal to the sum of the components in subsection 1, paragraphs A to 34 
E by fiscal year 2023 -24.  In making this calculation, the commissio ner shall ensure 35 
that the annual adjustment calculated pursuant to this paragraph is reasonably similar 36 
over the course of the transition period.  37 
C.  During each fiscal year of the transition period, the commissioner shall adjust the 38 
total allocation for e ach career and technical education center and career and 39 
technical education region identified pursuant to paragraph A in accordance with the 40 
calculation under paragraph B.  41

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART BBBBB  1 
Sec. BBBBB -1.  Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce Issues.   2 
Notwithstanding Joint Rule 353, the Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce 3 
Issues, referred to in this section as "the commission," is established.  4 
1.  Members.   The commission consists of up to 18 members as follows:  5 
A. Two members of the Senate appoin ted by the President of the Senate, including a 6 
member from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of seats in the 7 
Legislature;  8 
B. Three members of the House of Representatives appointed by the Speaker of the 9 
House, including a member from each o f the 2 parties holding the largest number of 10 
seats in the Legislature; and  11 
C. Up to 13 members who possess expertise in the subject matter of the study as 12 
follows:  13 
(1) A direct care worker appointed by the President of the Senate;  14 
(2) A provider of home -based long -term care who is a member of a statewide 15 
association representing home -based long -term care providers appointed by the 16 
President of the Senate;  17 
(3) A representative of a statewide association representing nonprofit housing and 18 
senior service prog ramming appointed by the President of the Senate;  19 
(4) A representative of an organization providing services to individuals with 20 
intellectual disabilities and autism including employment services and long -term 21 
home supports appointed by the President of th e Senate;  22 
(5) A provider of facility -based long -term care who is a member of a statewide 23 
association representing facility -based long -term care providers appointed by the 24 
Speaker of the House;  25 
(6) A representative of an organization providing statewide hom emaker services 26 
through the state -funded independent support services program within the 27 
Department of Health and Human Services appointed by the Speaker of the 28 
House;  29 
(7) A representative of an institution of higher education engaged in workforce 30 
developm ent appointed by the Speaker of the House;  31 
(8) A representative of a service coordination agency providing service 32 
coordination to people receiving home -based and community -based long -term 33 
care appointed by the Speaker of the House;  34 
(9) A representative of  an organization promoting independent living for 35 
individuals with disabilities appointed by the Speaker of the House;  36 
(10) A representative of a business that acts as a labor intermediary helping 37 
unemployed and underemployed people obtain employment appoi nted by the 38 
Speaker of the House;  39 
(11) The executive director of the long -term care ombudsman program described 40 
under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 22, section 5106, subsection 11 -C; 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 596 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (12) The Commissioner of Health and Human Services, or the commission er's 1 
designee, who may be invited to participate; and  2 
(13) The Commissioner of Labor, or the commissioner's designee, who may be 3 
invited to participate.  4 
2. Chairs and subcommittees.  The first -named Senate member is the Senate chair 5 
and the first -named Hous e of Representatives member is the House chair of the 6 
commission. The chairs of the commission are authorized to establish subcommittees to 7 
work on the duties listed in subsection 4 and to assist the commission. The 8 
subcommittees must be composed of member s of the commission and interested persons 9 
who are not members of the commission and who volunteer to serve on the 10 
subcommittees without reimbursement.  11 
3. Appointments.  All appointments must be made no later than 30 days following 12 
the effective date of thi s Part. The appointing authorities shall notify the Executive 13 
Director of the Legislative Council once all appointments have been completed. After 14 
appointment of all members and after adjournment of the First Regular Session of the 15 
129th Legislature, the c hairs shall call and convene the first meeting of the commission. 16 
If 30 days or more after the effective date of this Part a majority of but not all 17 
appointments have been made, the chairs may request authority and the Legislative 18 
Council may grant authori ty for the commission to meet and conduct its business.  19 
4.  Directive of commission.  The commission shall study and make policy 20 
recommendations in each of the following areas:  21 
A. Measuring current demand for direct care workers and projecting future needs;  22 
B. Developing a campaign and statewide recruitment strategies to encourage more 23 
people to work in facility -based and home -based long -term care;  24 
C.  Supporting career ladders throughout various long -term care settings;  25 
D. Identifying education needs and me thods to fill education needs for direct care 26 
workers;  27 
E. Identifying barriers to hiring and methods to overcome barriers to hiring;  28 
F. Developing strategies to improve the quality of long -term care jobs; and  29 
G. Increasing opportunities for shared staffing  among long -term care providers.  30 
The commission shall make policy recommendations for public and private funding 31 
mechanisms to implement the commission's recommendations.  32 
5. Program.  The commission shall make recommendations for the establishment of a 33 
program that will contribute to long -term care direct care workers' postsecondary 34 
education in related fields.  35 
6. Pilot program.  The commission shall make recommendations for the 36 
establishment of a pilot program to pool part -time home care workers' hours for p urposes 37 
of providing greater employment opportunity and obtaining employee benefits.  38 
7.  Staffing.  The Legislative Council shall provide necessary staffing services to the 39 
commission, except that Legislative Council staff support is not authorized when the  40 
Legislature is in regular or special session.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 597 - 129LR2405(03) -1

suggested legislation, to the Joint Standing Committee on Health and Hum an Services. 6

PART CCCCC  9 
Sec. CCCCC -1.  25 MRSA §5101, as amended by PL 2017, c. 407, Pt. A, §104, 10 
is furth er amended to read:  11 
§5101.  Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program  12 
1.  Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program.  The Substance Use Disorder 13 
Assistance Program , referred to in this chapter as "the program,"  is established to support 14 
persons with presum ed substance use disorder by providing grants to municipalities and 15 
counties to carry out projects  programs  designed to reduce substance use, substance use - 16 
related crimes and recidivism.  17 
2.  Eligibility; program targets; programs.  Grants may be awarded to : 18 
A.  Municipal or county governments or regional jails for projects  programs  designed 19 
to assist persons with presumed substance use disorder by diverting  using liaison 20 
strategies both before and after arrest to refer  alleged low -level offenders into 21 
commu nity-based treatment and support services.  Projects  Programs  may include, 22 
but are not limited to:  23 
(1)  Referral of program  participants in the Substance Use Disorder Assistance 24 
Program under subsection 1  to evidence -based treatment programs, including 25 
medically assisted treatment; and  26 
(2)  Provision of case management services to program  participants in the 27 
Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program under subsection 1  in order to 28 
secure appropriate treatment and support services such as housing, health care , 29 
job training and mental health services for program  participants in the Substance 30 
Use Disorder Assistance Program ; and 31 
B.  County governments or regional jails  for projects  programs  in county or regional  32 
jails designed to assist  facilitate the accessing by persons with presumed substance 33 
use disorder of post -adjudication diversion and reentry programs .  Projects  Programs  34 
may include, but are not limited to:  35 
(1)  Provision of evidence -based treatment programs, including medically 36 
assisted treatment, to jai l inmates; and  37 
(2)  Provision of case management or other support services to program  38 
participants in the Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program under subsection 39 
1 to assist in transition from jail upon release .; and  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 598 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  Municipal governments for progra ms designed to facilitate pathways to 1 
community -based treatment, recovery and support services for persons with 2 
substance use disorder who present themselves to municipal law enforcement 3 
agencies and request assistance and referral to evidence -based treatm ent programs, 4 
including medically assisted treatment.  5 
3.  Requirements.  A grant application for a project  program  described in subsection 6 
2 must include the following:  7 
A.  A statement of purpose and measurable goals for the project  program  and use for 8 
the funds; and 9 
B.  The elements of the project  program , which must include the targeted population, 10 
the nature of services or assistance to be provided and expected outcomes ;. 11 
C.  For diversion projects, a statement of the municipality's or county's diversion  12 
policy, including criteria for selecting participants for the project;  13 
D.  A review of other substance use disorder services available in the applicant 14 
municipality or county and communities adjacent to the applicant municipality or 15 
county and a statement  of the unmet needs to be addressed by the project;  16 
E.  A review of efforts to collaborate among relevant law enforcement agencies, 17 
treatment providers, harm reduction services, recovery support services and other 18 
community resources and a summary of colla borative approaches included in the 19 
project, if any; and  20 
F.  A summary of data to be collected to assess the effectiveness of the project and 21 
the methodology that will be used to make that assessment.  The data to be collected 22 
must include measurements of the long -term health, treatment and criminal justice 23 
involvement outcomes for participants and must be included in reports filed under 24 
subsection 6 as part of a rigorous evaluation process.  25 
4.  Selection of grant recipients.  The Commissioner of Public Saf ety shall review 26 
applications submitted by municipalities and, counties and regional jails  for grants under 27 
this chapter.  Preference must be given to collaborative approaches that include treatment 28 
providers or community -based organizations.  The followin g steering committee shall 29 
advise the Commissioner of Public Safety in selecting grant recipients.  The steering 30 
committee consists of the Commissioner of Corrections or the commissioner's designee 31 
and representatives of the following organizations, progra ms and associations selected by 32 
the Commissioner of Public Safety from suggestions provided by the organizations, 33 
programs and associations:  a statewide organization of police chiefs; a statewide 34 
organization of sheriffs; a statewide organization represen ting physicians; a statewide 35 
organization representing prosecutors; a statewide organization representing providers of 36 
legal services for the indigent; peer recovery programs; and harm reduction associations.  37 
5.  Administration of funds.  The policy board established in this State to carry out 38 
the State's responsibilities under the federal Justice Assistance Act of 1984, the federal 39 
Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, the federal Anti -Drug Abuse Act of 1988 and the federal 40 
Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement  Act of 1994, known as "the Justice 41 
Assistance Council," shall administer grant funds appropriated for use under this chapter  42 
and disburse the funds to municipalities, counties and regional jails selected under 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 599 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  subsection 4.  The department may retain up t o 5% of funds to cover administrative 1 
expenses . 2

Commissioner of Public Safety annually on the anniversary date of the grant award 4 
regarding the status of the project  program  for wh ich the grant was awarded.  The report 5

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1.  Reim bursement.  The department shall reimburse services provided to 1 
MaineCare member adults with intellectual disabilities or autism under a waiver granted 2 
by the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for home -based and 3 
community -based care on the  basis of rates and a methodology established by major 4 
substantive rulemaking and that includes a rate for direct care workers, as defined in 5 
section 1717, subsection 1, paragraph A -3, that is no less than 125% of the minimum 6
