every 2 years, conduct a substantive review of the rates set under this section.  The review 8 
must provide for public comment.  This section applies to all funds, including federal 9 
funds, paid by an y agency of the State to a provider for care covered by the waiver.  10

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 601 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the United States Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Medicare and 1 
Medicaid Services pursuant to section 1, shall amend th e department's rule Chapter 101:  2 
MaineCare Benefits Manual, Chapter II, Section 19 to allow for spouses to be employed 3 
as personal support specialists for eligible members.  A spouse may be reimbursed only 4 
for providing extraordinary care and services tha t the spouse is not normally expected to 5 
provide.  The department shall adopt any rules necessary regarding the specific services 6 
that may be provided by a spouse under the waiver.  Reimbursement for services 7 
provided by a spouse may not exceed the cap and  limits in department rules.  8

II, Section 19 who employ personal support specialists who are spouses; the costs or 17

programs or other potential waivers available under Medicaid.  The joint standing 20 
committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over health and human services matters 21 
may report out a bill to the First Regular Session of the 130th Legislature regarding any 22 
recommendations contained in the report.  23

kindergarten to grade 12, the state contribution and the annual target state share 37

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART E  1 
 2 
This Part authorizes the Maine Governmental Facilities Authority to issue additional 3 
securities in an amount up to $55,000,000 to pay for the costs of capit al repairs and 4 
improvements to and construction of state -owned facilities and hazardous waste cleanup 5 
on state -owned properties.  6 
PART F  7 
 8 
This Part revises the selection of the chair of the Revenue Forecasting Committee, 9 
beginning in calendar year 2019, to designation by the 6 members, from among the 10 
members excluding the State Budget Officer, on a rotating basis for a 2 -year term.  The 11 
exclusion is to avoid a conflict with the duties of the State Budget Officer established in 12 
current law that include conven ing a meeting of the Revenue Forecasting Committee if 13 
new information becomes available.  14 
PART G  15 
 16 
This Part implements background investigations for certain individuals with a 17 
business need to receive federal tax information, in order to meet United States Internal 18 
Revenue Service standards.  This Part also expands background checks to apply to all 19 
employees of the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Maine Revenue 20 
Services.  21 
This Part also corrects numerous lettering conflicts that occurred w hen 2 separate 22 
public laws enacted substantively different laws with the same paragraph letters.  23 
PART H  24 
 25 
This Part provides property tax relief to the residents of this State in the following 26 
ways.  27 
This Part sets the transfer to the Local Government Fund f or state -municipal revenue 28 
sharing at 3% in fiscal year 2019 -20 and 3.75% in fiscal year 2020 -2021.  A municipality 29 
that has already established its budget for 2019 is restricted in how it can spend the 30 
additional amount of revenue sharing received above t he amount of revenue sharing 31 
assumed in that municipality's budget and the amount of revenue sharing received 32 
pursuant to this Part.  That excess revenue may be spent without obtaining approval 33 
through that municipality's budget process if the revenue is u sed for repair and 34 
maintenance of roads and bridges or for the direct reduction of the mill rate in that 35 
municipality.  36 
This Part also increases for property tax years beginning April 1, 2020 the value of 37 
the homestead exemption benefit under the Maine resi dent homestead property tax 38 
exemption from $20,000 to $25,000 and increases the state reimbursement to 39 
municipalities for the lost property tax revenue from 62.5% to 70%.  40 
This Part changes the formula for calculation of the property tax fairness credit to 41 
expand the credit to residents whose property taxes or rent constituting property taxes on 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P . 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 603 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  homestead property exceeds 5%, rather than 6% in the current law, of the residents' 1 
income for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2020.  2

growth.  37

for the increase.  Based on that information, the Commissioner of Education is required to 17 
provide to each school administrative unit the funds necessary to fund the incremental 18 
salary increases.  19

 Page 610 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part amends the preference  in state hiring that grants an interview to a person 1 
with a disability who meets the minimum qualifications for any open position in order to 2 
comply with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act.  If the person is not selected for 3 
the position, the Dep artment of Administrative and Financial Services, Bureau of Human 4 
Resources must provide guidance to the person regarding other available state positions 5 
for which the person might qualify.  The bureau may also refer the person to the 6 
Department of Labor, Bureau of Rehabilitation Services for vocational rehabilitation 7 
services, including opportunities in the special appointment program.  8

PART SSS  14 
 15 
This Part allows the Commissioner of Health and Human Services in consultation 16 
with the Superintendent of Insurance to apply for a waiver of applicable provi sions of the 17 
federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act with respect to health insurance 18 
coverage in the State for the purposes of improving affordability.  The commissioner may 19 
implement a state plan meeting the waiver requirements in a manner con sistent with state 20 
and federal law, and the state plan may not increase cost sharing or reduce the 21 
comprehensiveness of coverage.  The authorization to submit a waiver expires if a waiver 22 
application has not been submitted by June 30, 2022.  23

This Part modernizes laws concerning the Department of Labor, Bureau of 30 
Rehabilitation Services and the Public U tilities Commission relating to 31 
telecommunications equipment funding for the deaf and hard of hearing to reflect 32 
changes in technology and the use of such services by individuals with disabilities.  This 33 
Part repeals the requirement that a person who is ce rtified as being deaf, hard of hearing 34 
or late deafened and whose income is less than 135% of the federal poverty level must 35 
receive a discount of up to $10 per month in the service charge for a device used to 36 
receive emergency alerts and repeals the provi sion of law that provides the Public 37 
Utilities Commission authority to transfer funds to support the discount.  38

PART UUUU  14 
 15 
This Part provides that it is the goal of the State to provide adequate start -up funding 16 
to ensure that public preschool programs  for children 4 years of age are offered by all 17 
school administrative units by the 2023 -2024 school year and requires the Department of 18 
Education to include in its funding recommendations funding options to encourage more 19 
public preschool programs.  20 
In orde r to achieve this goal, this Part requires the Department of Education to 21 
develop recommendations and report back to the Joint Standing Committee on Education 22 
and Cultural Affairs by January 1, 2020.  Recommendations must include:  23 
1. Standards for public p reschool programs;  24 
2. A process for approval and certification of programs not operated by a school 25 
administrative unit, including, but not limited to, a Head Start program or other program 26 
affiliated with the school administrative unit; and  27 
3. Funding fo r public preschool programs.  28 
The Joint Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs may report out 29 
legislation to the Second Regular Session of the 129th Legislature to implement the 30 
recommendations in the report.  31

This Part allows the School Revolving Renovation Fund to be used for renovations to 15 
retrofit learning spaces to accommodate the provision of services for children with 16 
disabilities who are 3 to 5 years of age, and the renovations receive Priority 4 status.  This 17 
Part also repeals the requirement that the School Revolving Renovation Fund be used to 18 
provide grants to forgive the principal payments of a loan for an eligible school 19 
administrative unit and corrects cross -references to that provision.  20 
PART AAAAA  21 
 22 
This Part requires the Department of Education to provide a so -called hold harmless 23 
adjustment to the career and technical education centers and career and technical 24 
education regions in fiscal y ears 2020 -21, 2021 -22 and 2022 -23 in order to transition the 25 
career and technical education centers and career and technical education regions to a 26 
total allocation that is equal to the sum of the career and technical education program 27 
components under the  Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, section 15688 -A, subsection 1 28 
by fiscal year 2023 -24. 29 
PART BBBBB  30 
 31 
This Part establishes the Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce Issues to 32 
study and make policy recommendations regarding direct care workers, inc luding 33 
determining the current and future demand for direct care workers, methods of 34 
encouraging employment in the direct care worker field and improving the quality of 35 
long-term care jobs.  The commission is required to submit a report to the Joint Standi ng 36 
Committee on Health and Human Services by November 7, 2019.  37 
PART CCCCC  38 
 39 
This Part amends the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 25, chapter 601, the Substance 40 
Use Disorder Assistance Program.  This Part: changes language referencing "pilot 41 
projects" to inste ad reference "programs"; eliminates program requirements that pertain to 42 
pilot projects; eliminates the steering committee that provides advice on the selection of 43 
grant recipients; repeals the requirement that the Justice Assistance Council disburse 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “B” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 616 - 129LR2405(03) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  funds ; and eliminates the authority of the Department of Public Safety to retain up to 5% 1 
of funds to cover administrative expenses.  2 
PART DDDDD  3 
 4 
This Part carries forward unexpended All Other funds as of June 30, 2019 and June 5 
30, 2020 in the Department of Publ ic Safety, Administration - Public Safety program, 6 
General Fund account to the next fiscal years in order to provide $750,000 per year in 7 
fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21 for grants for the provision of community -based 8 
treatment and support services throug h the Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program.  9 
PART EEEEE  10 
 11 
This Part requires the State Controller to transfer $1,035,000 from available balances 12 
in Other Special Revenue Funds accounts in the Department of Environmental Protection, 13 
the Department of Mar ine Resources or the Department of Education to the Department 14 
of Marine Resources, Nonfederal Grants, Other Special Revenue Funds account, based on 15 
the determination of the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services.  16 
PART FFFFF  17 
 18 
This Part speci fies that the MaineCare reimbursement rate for direct care workers for 19 
adults with intellectual disabilities or autism must be at least 125% of the state minimum 20 
wage.  21 
PART GGGGG  22 
 23 
This Part eliminates the requirement that the State Fire Marshal inspect a f amily 24 
foster home and certify that it meets all elements of the fire safety code before the 25 
Department of Health and Human Services may issue a license to operate as a family 26 
foster home.  This Part moves the inspection responsibility to the Department of Health 27 
and Human Services, which is directed to adopt rules governing the method of inspection.  28 
PART HHHHH  29 
 30 
This Part requires the Department of Health and Human Services to submit a request 31 
to the United States Department of Health and Human Services, Cen ters for Medicare and 32 
Medicaid Services to amend the current federal 1915(c) waiver so that eligible members 33 
receiving home and community -based services under the department's rule Chapter 101:  34 
MaineCare Benefits Manual, Chapter II, Section 19 will be abl e to receive services 35 
provided by spouses who are employed as personal support specialists to provide those 36 
services.  It requires the department to amend its rules after the amended waiver approval 37 
has been received from the Federal Government.  The Part requires the department to 38 
provide an interim report regarding the progress in applying for, receiving and 39 
implementing the amended waiver and a final report with data on the number of 40 
individuals receiving services from spouses, any information about cost s or savings and 41 
recommendations about the feasibility for similarly expanding other MaineCare programs 42 
or other potential waiver programs available under Medicaid.  43
